pageProps.contentHtml:
entire functions, inverse function theorem

Let fff, ggg, and hhh be complex-valued functions defined on C\CC with

f=g∘h.f = g \circ h.f=g∘h.

Show that if hhh is continuous, and both fff and ggg are non-constant and holomorphic, then hhh is holomorphic as well.
Solution.

Let B={z∈C∣g′(z)=0}B = \set{z \in \C \mid g'\p{z} = 0}B={z∈C∣g′(z)=0}. Since ggg is non-constant and entire, BBB must be at most countable (it can have only finitely many zeroes on any compact ball). Thus, given z∈C∖h−1(B)z \in \C \setminus h^{-1}\p{B}z∈C∖h−1(B), we see that g′(h(z))≠0g'\p{h\p{z}} \neq 0g′(h(z))=0, so ggg is biholomorphic on a neighborhood UUU of h(z)h\p{z}h(z). Consequently,

h=(g∣U)−1∘fh = \p{\res{g}{U}}^{-1} \circ fh=(g∣U​)−1∘f

on h−1(U)h^{-1}\p{U}h−1(U), so hhh is holomorphic at zzz and so holomorphic on all of C∖h−1(B)\C \setminus h^{-1}\p{B}C∖h−1(B).

Let z∈Bz \in Bz∈B so that g′(h(z))=0g'\p{h\p{z}} = 0g′(h(z))=0. Notice that f(z)=g(h(z))f\p{z} = g\p{h\p{z}}f(z)=g(h(z)), and because fff is holomorphic near zzz and ggg near h(z)h\p{z}h(z), it follows that hhh must be bounded near zzz. To complete the proof, we simply need to show that zzz is isolated in BBB.

Suppose otherwise, and that {zn}n⊆B\set{z_n}_n \subseteq B{zn​}n​⊆B with zn≠z0z_n \neq z_0zn​=z0​ converges to z0z_0z0​. We claim that h(zn)=h(z0)h\p{z_n} = h\p{z_0}h(zn​)=h(z0​) for at most finitely many nnn. Otherwise, we get a subsequence h(znk)=h(z0)h\p{z_{n_k}} = h\p{z_0}h(znk​​)=h(z0​) and

f(znk)=g(h(znk))=g(h(z0)),f\p{z_{n_k}} = g\p{h\p{z_{n_k}}} = g\p{h\p{z_0}},f(znk​​)=g(h(znk​​))=g(h(z0​)),

which implies that the zeroes of f(z)−f(z0)f\p{z} - f\p{z_0}f(z)−f(z0​) accumulate, which is impossible as fff is non-constant. Thus, by reindexing, we may assume that h(zn)≠h(z0)h\p{z_n} \neq h\p{z_0}h(zn​)=h(z0​) for all nnn. But this implies that g′(h(zn))=0g'\p{h\p{z_n}} = 0g′(h(zn​))=0 and g′(h(z0))=0g'\p{h\p{z_0}} = 0g′(h(z0​))=0, which means that the zeroes of g′g'g′ have an accumulation point, so g′g'g′ is constant. By assumption this means g′=g′(h(z0))=0g' = g'\p{h\p{z_0}} = 0g′=g′(h(z0​))=0, which implies ggg is constant, a contradiction. Hence, no accumulation point could have existed to begin with, so BBB is an isolated. By Riemann's removable singularity theorem, hhh extends to an entire function, as required.
